title: Black Orchid
dialogue_triumphs: 'From Brazil, where the nuts come from!'
goofs: Police boxes did not exist in the 1920s, so how do the policemen recognise the TARDIS?

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord protagonist of the series
continuity_notes.current_status: Reveals childhood desire to drive a steam engine

continuity_notes.name: Tegan
continuity_notes.current_status: Enjoys cricket, can Charleston, and orders a screwdriver at a cocktail party

continuity_notes.name: Nyssa
continuity_notes.current_status: Concerned about TARDIS safety after recent events in London

roots: H. P. Lovecraft's The Shuttered Room
Works of Agatha Christie, Margery Allingham and Dorothy L. Sayers
links: The story follows directly from 'The Visitation'
Sir Robert thinks that Traken is near Esher
Lord Cranleigh believes Alzarius is a Baltic state
Reference to 'the Master' in episode one
additional_notes: The Doctor sings 'I Want to Be Happy' from No, No, Nanette. The Doctor and his companions stay for George's funeral and are given his book Black Orchid as a parting gift by Lady Cranleigh.
bottom_line: 'Quite topping!' A little piece of 20s whimsy sampled into Doctor Who with surprisingly satisfying results. The only SF-free historically-based Doctor Who story after 1966.
